Thrown when the passed oDataSourceMetaData contains one or more Rows with a non-numeric, non null-string value in 'MinimumNumericValue' or 'MamimumNumericValue'. Thrown when the passed oDataSourceMetaData contains one or more Rows with a mismatched pair of MinimumNumericValue/MamimumNumericValue (a pair must both be numeric or both be null-strings). ############################################################ May 9, 2007

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumDataTypes.cnBoolean
member.remarks: NOTE: Inputs defined as cnBooleans always return values based on MakeBooleanInteger, where zero equates to false and non-zero equates to true.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumDataTypes.cnChar
member.summary:
"Short" character data type.
"Short" character types are defined as character types where the data source allows "equal to" and "not equal to" comparisons on the columns.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumDataTypes.cnLongChar
member.summary:
"Long" character data type.
"Long" character types are defined as character types where the data source does not allow "equal to" and "not equal to" comparisons on the columns.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumMetaDataTypes.cnData_Type
member.summary: Generalized column data type as defined within enumDataTypes.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumMetaDataTypes.cnNumeric_Precision
member.summary: Maximum number of significant digits allowed.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumMetaDataTypes.cnNumeric_Scale
member.summary: Numeric scale (number of digits the decimal point has been shifted).

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumMetaDataTypes.cnMinimumNumericValue
member.summary: String representing the minimum allowed numeric value.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumMetaDataTypes.cnMamimumNumericValue
member.summary: String representing the maximum allowed numeric value.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumMetaDataTypes.cnRelatedPicklist
member.summary: String representing the name of the Picklist related to the column.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumValueTypes.cnVerbatum
member.summary:
Verbatum type.
Value is not automaticially validated for range, length or data type.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumValueTypes.cnSingleValueFromPicklist
member.summary:
Single value from picklist.
Value refers to a single related enumerated value.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumValueTypes.cnMultiValuesFromPicklist
member.summary:
Multiple values from picklist.
Common delimited value refers to one or more related enumerated values.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumValueErrorTypes.cnIncorrectDataType
member.summary: Submitted value is of an incorrect type.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumValueErrorTypes.cnValueIsRequired
member.summary: A value is required for this input.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumValueErrorTypes.cnNotWithinPicklist
member.summary: Submitted value is not within the picklist.

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumValueErrorTypes.cnUnknownOrUnsupportedType
member.summary: Input data type is of an unknown or unsupported type (so Renderer cannot validate its value).

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumValueErrorTypes.cnCustom
member.summary: Custom error (developer should define their own error message).

member.name: F:Cn.Data.MetaData.enumValueErrorTypes.cnMissingInput
member.summary: A defined input is missing from the HTML form.

member.summary: Multiple values were submitted for an input defined as a single value.

############################################################
Called by the ASP.NET page framework to notify server controls that use composition-based implementation to create any child controls they contain in preperation for posting back or rendering.
############################################################ June 2, 2010

############################################################
Creates the control(s) for the specified page section of the WebControl.
Enumeration representing the referenced page section. Integer representing the index of the data item in the data source. Object representing the value to use when data-binding operations are preformed. ############################################################ June 2, 2010

############################################################
Renders the control(s) for the specified page section of the WebControl.
Enumeration representing the referenced page section. ############################################################ June 28, 2010

############################################################
Translates the provided page section into it's related template.
Enumeration representing the referenced page section. ITemplate object representing the related template. ############################################################ May 31, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets the data source that is provided to the items within the control.
Object (optonally containing a list of values) that is provided to the items within the control. ############################################################ February 11, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets the results set related to this instance.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own Results property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
String representation of a Pagination object that represents this instance's results set. ############################################################ February 8, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets the count of records per rendered page (not including new records).
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own RecordsPerPage property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
NOTE: This property does not make much sense for Reports as Reports would generally represent the entire set of results (i.e. a RecordsPerPage value of "0"). But if you choose to only represent X records on a given report, you can utilize this property. Do note however that RecordsPerPage refers to records rendered per page load, *NOT* per phisically printed page!
1-based integer representing the count of records per rendered page (not including new records). ############################################################ February 8, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets a value representing the default SQL Order By Clause for the current instance.
The OrderBy clause is set by default based on the following order of prescience:
1) OrderBy equals the querystring's "OrderBy" field, as defined by the end-user (as long as it's safe).
2) Failing 1, OrderBy equals this instance's Results' "OrderedBy" field, as defined by the end-user (as long as it's safe).
3) Failing 1 and 2, OrderBy equals the DefaultOrderBy, as defined by the developer (as long as it's safe).
4) Failing 1, 2 and 3, OrderBy equals a null-string.
OrderBy clause values set via the OrderBy property overwrite this default value.
NOTE: This value is meaningless for Reports as the value is always sourced from the underlying List or Form.
String representing the default SQL order by clause for the current instance. ############################################################ February 8, 2010

############################################################
Get/sets a value indicating the total height of a printed page.
Due to the web's poor ability to format pages for printing, this method of counting the current number of units (inches, cm, mm, etc.) the current text would be on a printed page was devised. For example - if one record occupys approximately 1 inch of vertical page space, the top of the forth record would start at approximately 3 inches down the page. Though not perfect, this method allows the developer to better accommodate the printed page by controlling where page breaks occur.
NOTE: The units you choose to return from this function (inches, cm, mm, etc.) are irrelevant, so long as they agree with the units returned by the PageLength functions in the related List, Form and/or Report.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own PageLength property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
1-based integer representing the total height of a printed page in a unit of measure. ############################################################ February 8, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets a value indicating if we are in printable mode.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own Printable property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
Boolean value indicating if we are in printable mode. ############################################################ February 8, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets a value indicating if we are in debug mode.
When enabled, this functionality utilizes carrage return/line feed character(s) during rendering, as well as the non-compresssed JavaScript oFiles in order to ease debugging.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own Debug property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
Boolean value indicating if we are in debug mode. ############################################################ February 8, 2010

Renderer.List object that manages this instance. ############################################################ February 9, 2010

System.Web.UI.ControlCollection object that represents the child controls for a specified server control in the UI hierarchy. ############################################################ June 1, 2010

############################################################
Gets a value representing if this instance has been data bound.
Boolean value representing if this instance has been data bound. ############################################################ February 15, 2010

members.member:
############################################################
Initializes the class.
Enumeration representing the object type of this instance. String representing the class path of this instance.
############################################################ March 18, 2010

############################################################
Resets the class to its initilized state.
Cn.Web.Settings.Current instance representing the current enviroment. ############################################################ June 1, 2010

############################################################
Renders the requested general input.
NOTE: cnComplexSorter is not yet implemented.
For a cnQuickSearch type, sAdditionalData equates to the quicksearch form's initial search criteria. oAdditionalData equates to a string representing the quicksearch form text input's additional attributes.
For a cnUserSelectedStackCheckbox type, sAdditionalData equates to the current record's ID. oAdditionalData equates to a Hashtable of string containing values for the "FormName" (required), "TableName", "IDColumn", "UserSelectedStack" and the checkbox's additional "Attributes".
Enumeration representing the general input type to render. String representing the additional data required by the general input. Object representing the additional data required by the general input. Thrown when the passed eGeneralInputType is unreconized. Thrown when a eGeneralInputType of cnUserSelectedStackCheckbox is requested and the passed oAdditionalData's (casted as a Hashtable of strings) key "FormName" contains a null-string. String representing the requested XHTML/DHTML control. ############################################################ January 8, 2010

############################################################
Collects/reorders the entire results set.
Required function overload to collect the entire results set of relevant record IDs.
If the page has no results or results that need to be re-ordered, this function is called by the Class Constructor. This function is not called if there are results that are properly ordered.
Pagination object representing entire result set's record IDs. Boolean value indicating if the entire results set requires re-ordering. ############################################################ June 2, 2004

############################################################
Collects the provided page results.
Required function overload to collect a page's relevant records as referenced within the passed rPageResults.
If the page has results, this function is called after GenerateResults or the Class Constructor (depending on the state of the provided sResultsStack). This function is not called if there are no records to render.
NOTE: The rPageResults parameter is equivalent to this code snipit: rPageResults = Renderer.Results.getRange(Renderer.Index, Renderer.List.RecordsPerPage)
Pagination object representing this page's relevant record IDs. ############################################################ May 30, 2007

############################################################
Returns the length the passed page section crawls down a printed page.
Optionally overload this function to define your own print length definition.
This function is called once per page section when a Renderer.Report is being rendered in print mode. This means that you can calculate the page crawl on a per record basis if need be.
Due to the web's poor ability to format pages for printing, this method of counting the current number of units (inches, cm, mm, etc.) the current text would be on a printed page was devised. For example - if one record occupies approximately 1 inch of vertical page space, the top of the forth record would start at approximately 3 inches down the page. Though not perfect, this method allows the developer to better accommodate the printed page by controlling where page breaks occur.
NOTE: The units you choose to return from this function (inches, cm, mm, etc.) are irrelevant, so long as they agree with the units returned by the PageLength functions in the related RendererList, RendererForm and/or RendererReport.
Integer representing the page crawl in units for the referenced ePageSection. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Outputs the header section of the rendered page.
Optionally overload this function to define your own page section.
If the page has results, this function is called after CollectPageResults. If the page has no results, this function is called after GenerateResults or the Class Constructor (depending on the state of the provided sResultsStack). This function is called for every page render.
############################################################ May 19, 2004

############################################################
Outputs the no results section of the rendered page.
Optionally overload this function to define your own page section.
If the page has no results, this function is called after Header. This function is not called if there are records to render.
############################################################ May 19, 2004

############################################################
Outputs the footer section of the rendered page.
Optionally overload this function to define your own page section.
If the page has results, this function is called after DetailFooter. If the page has no results, this function is called after NoResults. This function is called for every page render.
############################################################ May 19, 2004

############################################################
Renders the revelent section of the provided list.
Required function overload to render the revelent section of the provided list.
1-based integer representing the maximum number of records so show per rendered page (does not include new records). String representing the related Data.Pagination instance. ############################################################ May 21, 2007

############################################################
Renders the revelent section of the provided list.
Required function overload to render the revelent section of the provided list.
1-based integer representing the maximum number of records so show per rendered page (does not include new records). Array of strings representing all the expected IDs to render (including IDs that may no longer be available). String representing the order the passed sIDsOrderedBy is in. ############################################################ November 19, 2009

############################################################
Renders the provided list.
PaginationTable object representing the relevant record IDs for the current table index. ############################################################ April 21, 2010

############################################################
Outputs the detail and missing record sections (as required) of the rendered page.
PaginationTable object representing the relevant record IDs for the current table index. ############################################################ March 18, 2010

############################################################
Calculates the unit of measure crawl down the current page.
NOTE: If the passed iSectionLength does not fit on the current page, an implicit page break is inserted.
1-based integer representing the length of the current section. ############################################################ August 31, 2005

############################################################
Calculates the unit of measure crawl down the current page for a Detail or MissingRecord section.
NOTE: If v1.x of C# supported Templates (or, in C# vanicular: Generics) this could be implemented with a single definition. But since dotNet 1.x does not support Templates (Generics) we do it in 2 definitions below which differ only in their signatures ("List oListForm" -vs- "Form oListForm").
List or Form object reference to the list/form class to render. Reference to a boolean value indicating if this is the initial or a subsequent function call (value is updated by reference). 1-based integer representing the length of the current list/form's Detail section. ############################################################ March 18, 2010

############################################################
Ensures that the provided section length is a positive number less then or equal to the PageLength.
1-based integer representing the length of the current section. 1-based integer representing the single page remainder length of the current section. ############################################################ August 31, 2004

############################################################
Determines if the provided section length fits on the current page.
1-based integer representing the length of the current section. Boolean value indicating if the passed iSectionLength fits on the current page. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Gets/sets the parent Report class related to this instance (if any).
NOTE: Reports are not permitted to have a Parent defined. Only Lists and Forms are permitted to have a non-null Parent.
Report object that represents the instance's related Report class (if any). ############################################################ January 10, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets the settings for this instance.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own Settings property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
Cn.Web.Settings.Current instance representing the current enviroment. ############################################################ March 4, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets a value representing the default SQL Order By Clause for the current instance.
The OrderBy clause is set by default based on the following order of prescience:
1) OrderBy equals the querystring's "OrderBy" field, as defined by the end-user (as long as it's safe).
2) Failing 1, OrderBy equals this instance's Results' "OrderedBy" field, as defined by the end-user (as long as it's safe).
3) Failing 1 and 2, OrderBy equals the DefaultOrderBy, as defined by the developer (as long as it's safe).
4) Failing 1, 2 and 3, OrderBy equals a null-string.
OrderBy clause values set via the OrderBy property overwrite this default value.
NOTE: This value is meaningless for Reports as the value is always sourced from the underlying List or Form.
String representing the default SQL order by clause for the current instance. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Get/sets a value indicating the total height of a printed page.
Due to the web's poor ability to format pages for printing, this method of counting the current number of units (inches, cm, mm, etc.) the current text would be on a printed page was devised. For example - if one record occupys approximately 1 inch of vertical page space, the top of the forth record would start at approximately 3 inches down the page. Though not perfect, this method allows the developer to better accommodate the printed page by controlling where page breaks occur.
NOTE: The units you choose to return from this function (inches, cm, mm, etc.) are irrelevant, so long as they agree with the units returned by the PageLength functions in the related List, Form and/or Report.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own PageLength property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
1-based integer representing the total height of a printed page in a unit of measure. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Gets/sets a value indicating if we are permitted to utilize Response.Write.
This is primarly in place to allow for "pseudo-renders" like that required during the CreateChildControl period of WebControls (as no rendering is actually done by the initial call). This can also be used by developers who choose to handle the rendering of their own page breaks and record trackers, should such a need arise.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own AllowResponseWrite property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
Boolean value indicating if we are permitted to utilize Response.Write. ############################################################ June 1, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets a value indicating if we are in printable mode.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own Printable property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
Boolean value indicating if we are in printable mode. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Gets/sets a value indicating if we are in debug mode.
When enabled, this functionality utilizes carrage return/line feed character(s) during rendering, as well as the non-compresssed JavaScript oFiles in order to ease debugging.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own Debug property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
Boolean value indicating if we are in debug mode. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Gets the Breadcrumb trail related to this instance.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own Breadcrumb property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
Breadcrumb object that represents this instance's Breadcrumb trail. ############################################################ November 9, 2009

############################################################
Gets the results set related to this instance.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own Results property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
Pagination object that represents this instance's results set. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Gets the user selected stack related to this instance.
String representing the related Data.Pagination instance for this instance's user selected stack. ############################################################ May 16, 2007

############################################################
Gets the carrage return/line feed character(s) utilized by this instance.
String representing the carrage return/line feed character(s) utilized by this instance. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Gets the count of records per rendered page (not including new records).
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own RecordsPerPage property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
NOTE: This property does not make much sense for Reports as Reports would generally represent the entire set of results (i.e. a RecordsPerPage value of "0"). But if you choose to only represent X records on a given report, you can utilize this property. Do note however that RecordsPerPage refers to records rendered per page load, *NOT* per phisically printed page!
1-based integer representing the count of records per rendered page (not including new records). ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Gets the current record's number (includes both existing and missing records).
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own RenderedRecordCount property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
1-based integer representing the current record's number (includes both existing and missing records). ############################################################ June 1, 2010

############################################################
Gets the current record's index (only includes existing records).
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own TableRecordIndex property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
0-based integer representing the current record's index (only includes existing records). ############################################################ June 22, 2010

############################################################
Gets the results stack's current table index.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own TableIndex property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
0-based integer representing the current table's index. ############################################################ June 1, 2010

############################################################
Gets a value indicating the current page number.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own PageCount property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
1-based integer representing the current page number. ############################################################ January 4, 2010

############################################################
Gets a value indicating the unit of measure crawl down the current page.
Due to the web's poor ability to format pages for printing, this method of counting the current number of units (inches, cm, mm, etc.) the current text would be on a printed page was devised. For example - if one record occupies approximately 1 inch of vertical page space, the top of the forth record would start at approximately 3 inches down the page. Though not perfect, this method allows the developer to better accommodate the printed page by controlling where page breaks occur.
NOTE: The units returned from this function (inches, cm, mm, etc.) are irrelevant, as they are based on the units returned by the PageLength functions in the related RendererList, RendererForm and/or RendererReport.
NOTE: If a Parent Report has been defined, this call is forwarded onto it's own PageCrawl property (as it is the Report that is responsible for the rendering of the List or Form).
1-based integer representing the unit of measure crawl down the current page. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################
Gets a value representing the object type of this instance.
Enumeration representing the object type of this instance. ############################################################ May 22, 2007

############################################################

############################################################ March 19, 2010

Renders the revelent section of the provided list.

Required function overload to render the revelent section of the provided list.

Array of strings representing all the expected IDs to render (including IDs that may no longer be available). String representing the order the passed sIDsOrderedBy is in. ############################################################ May 31, 2010

############################################################
Collects the page results in preperation for rendering.
NOTE: This function resets RecordsPerPage, TableRecordIndex, TableIndex, and RenderedRecordCount, loads the sResultsStack and returns the page ResultsStack in preperation for the List or Form render.
The OrderBy clause is set by default based on the following order of prescience:
1) OrderBy equals the querystring's "OrderBy" field, as defined by the end-user (as long as it's safe).
2) Failing 1, OrderBy equals this instance's Results' "OrderedBy" field, as defined by the end-user (as long as it's safe).
3) Failing 1 and 2, OrderBy equals the DefaultOrderBy, as defined by the developer (as long as it's safe).
4) Failing 1, 2 and 3, OrderBy equals a null-string.
OrderBy clause values set via the OrderBy property overwrite this default value.
1-based integer representing the maximum number of records so show per rendered page (does not include new records). String representing the related Data.Pagination instance. Array of strings representing all the expected IDs to render (including IDs that may no longer be available). String representing the order the passed sIDsOrderedBy is in. Pagination object representing the revelent section of the provided List or Form. ############################################################ March 19, 2010

############################################################
Renders the List/Form.
Pagination object representing this page's relevant record IDs. Boolean value representing if we are supposed to Reset the class with the current Settings after the render. ############################################################ June 22, 2010

############################################################
Outputs the header and detail header sections of the rendered page.
NOTE: We can get away with the get to inline cast of this into an IListForm because .cnReport's must override these virtual functions
############################################################ June 1, 2010

############################################################
Outputs the detail and missing record sections (as required) of the rendered page.
PaginationTable object representing the relevant record IDs for the current table index. ############################################################ June 22, 2010

############################################################
Outputs the detail header section of the rendered page.
Optionally overload this function to define your own page section.
If the page has results, this function is called after Header and before any records are rendered via the Detail and/or MissingRecord functions. This function is not called if there are no records to render.
If a printable Renderer.Report is being rendered, this function is called after each Report.PageHeader.
############################################################ May 19, 2004

############################################################
Outputs a detail section of the rendered page.
Optionally overload this function to define your own page section.
This function is called once per successfully collected record. This function is not called if there are no successfully collected records to render.
############################################################ June 21, 2004

############################################################
Outputs a missing record section of the rendered page.
Optionally overload this function to define your own page section.
This function is called once per missing record. This function is not called if there are no missing records to render.
############################################################ May 19, 2004

############################################################
Outputs the detail footer section of the rendered page.
Optionally overload this function to define your own page section.
If the page has results, this function is called after the last record is rendered via the Detail or MissingRecord function. This function is not called if there are no records to render.
If a printable Renderer.Report is being rendered, this function is called before each Report.PageFooter.
############################################################ May 19, 2004

############################################################
Gets/sets a boolean value representing if we are supposed to create the child controls of our parent webcontrol.
############################################################

############################################################
Initializes the class.
Cn.Web.Settings.Current instance representing the current enviroment. List object representing the parent WebControl.
############################################################ May 28, 2010

############################################################
Collects/reorders the entire results set.
Required function overload to collect the entire results set of relevant record IDs.
If the page has no results or results that need to be re-ordered, this function is called by the Class Constructor. This function is not called if there are results that are properly ordered.
Pagination object representing entire result set's record IDs. Boolean value indicating if the entire results set requires re-ordering. ############################################################ February 5, 2010

############################################################
Collects the provided page results.
Required function overload to collect a page's relevant records as referenced within the passed rPageResults.
If the page has results, this function is called after GenerateResults or the Class Constructor (depending on the state of the provided sResultsStack). This function is not called if there are no records to render.
NOTE: The rPageResults parameter is equivalent to this code snipit: rPageResults = Renderer.Results.getRange(Renderer.Index, Renderer.List.RecordsPerPage)
Pagination object representing this page's relevant record IDs. ############################################################ February 5, 2010

############################################################
Returns the length the passed page section crawls down a printed page.
This function is called once per page section when a Renderer.Report is being rendered in print mode. This means that you can calculate the page crawl on a per record basis if need be.
Due to the web's poor ability to format pages for printing, this method of counting the current number of units (inches, cm, mm, etc.) the current text would be on a printed page was devised. For example - if one record occupies approximately 1 inch of vertical page space, the top of the forth record would start at approximately 3 inches down the page. Though not perfect, this method allows the developer to better accommodate the printed page by controlling where page breaks occur.
NOTE: The units you choose to return from this function (inches, cm, mm, etc.) are irrelevant, so long as they agree with the units returned by the PageLength functions in the related RendererList, RendererForm and/or RendererReport.
Enumeration representing the referenced page section.
Integer representing the page crawl in units for the referenced ePageSection.
############################################################ February 10, 2010

############################################################
Outputs the header section of the rendered page.
If the page has results, this function is called after CollectPageResults. If the page has no results, this function is called after GenerateResults or the Class Constructor (depending on the state of the provided sResultsStack). This function is called for every page render.
############################################################ May 28, 2010

############################################################
Outputs the no results section of the rendered page.
If the page has no results, this function is called after Header. This function is not called if there are records to render.
############################################################ May 28, 2010

############################################################
Outputs the detail header section of the rendered page.
If the page has results, this function is called after Header and before any records are rendered via the Detail and/or MissingRecord functions. This function is not called if there are no records to render.
If a printable Renderer.Report is being rendered, this function is called after each Report.PageHeader.
############################################################ May 28, 2010

############################################################
Outputs a detail section of the rendered page.
This function is called once per successfully collected record. This function is not called if there are no successfully collected records to render.
############################################################ May 28, 2010

############################################################
Outputs a missing record section of the rendered page.
This function is called once per missing record. This function is not called if there are no missing records to render.
############################################################ May 28, 2010

############################################################
Outputs the detail footer section of the rendered page.
If the page has results, this function is called after the last record is rendered via the Detail or MissingRecord function. This function is not called if there are no records to render.
If a printable Renderer.Report is being rendered, this function is called before each Report.PageFooter.
############################################################ May 28, 2010

############################################################
Outputs the footer section of the rendered page.
If the page has results, this function is called after DetailFooter. If the page has no results, this function is called after NoResults. This function is called for every page render.
############################################################ May 28, 2010

This value is copied into the underlying Renderer.Form's Name property which is used to ensure that any rendered record tracker names are themselves unique.

############################################################

############################################################
Gets/sets a value indicating if we are to track record changes.
This function signals the Form to calculate MD5 hashs of the original and submitted records. If the hashs differ, then the end user made changes to the record and it therefore needs to be updated. If the hases match, then the end user didn't make any changes to the record, so there is no need to update the record.
This calculation's results are made available to the developer via the bRecordHasChanged argument of the RendererForm's ValidateRecord function. If this functionality is not enabled (i.e. - the value of this property is "false"), then the bRecordHasChanged argument of the RendererForm's ValidateRecord function is always "true".
Boolean value indicating if we are to track record changes. ############################################################ February 9, 2010

Boolean value indicating if the Form is to be rendered as read only. ############################################################ February 10, 2010

Parses the record tracker form element for the provided record number.
RecordTracker Example: "RecordType|TableIndex|TableRecordIndex|OriginalRecordMD5"
NOTE: This function is only utilized by Renderer.Form's and was only moved here to keep the RecordTracker functionality in a single place.

############################################################
Initializes the class.
Any SQL statements included within the a_sSQLStatements are returned to the developer in the order provided within the a_sSQL argument of SubmitResults in record order. These are followed by any SQL statements that were auto-generated based on the value of bGenerateSQL. For example, if the developer returned 2 SQL statements within the a_sSQLStatements for each record and requested that statements be auto-generated via bGenerateSQL, the a_sSQL argument of SubmitResults would be in the following order (assuming 2 records were submitted): Record1_SQLArrayStatement1, Record1_SQLArrayStatement2, Record1_GenerateSQLStatement1, Record2_SQLArrayStatement1, Record2_SQLArrayStatement2, Record2_GenerateSQLStatement1 NOTE: SQL statements (either provided via a_sSQLStatements or auto-generated) are only placed within the a_sSQL argument of SubmitResults if the record bIsValid. SQL statements for records with a bIsValid value of false are not included within the a_sSQL argument of SubmitResults.
Boolean value indicating if the record is valid. Boolean value indicating if the system is to automatically generate SQL queries for this record. String array where each element represents one developer defined SQL statement. ############################################################ January 11, 2010

This implementation does not render cnMultiValueFromPicklist or cnMultiValueSearchInSingleValuePicklist inputs. Call the multi value implementation to render cnMultiValueFromPicklist or cnMultiValueSearchInSingleValuePicklist inputs.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a SaveType set as cnSingleValuePicklistExType are:
cnSelect*, cnComboBox, cnOption, cnOptionListBox, cnHidden, cnReadOnly and cnDefaultInput.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a SaveType set as cnMultiValuePicklistExType are:
cnCheckboxes*, cnCheckedListBox, cnMultiSelect, cnHidden, cnReadOnly and cnDefaultInput.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a DataType set as cnBoolean are:
cnCheckbox*, cnOption, cnOptionListBox, cnSelect, cnHidden, cnReadOnly and cnDefaultInput.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a DataType set as cnInteger are:
cnText*, cnCheckbox, cnHidden, cnReadOnly and cnDefaultInput.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a DataType set as cnFloat or cnCurrency are:
cnText*, cnHidden, cnReadOnly and cnDefaultInput.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a DataType set as cnDateTime are:
cnDate*, cnTime, cnDateTime, cnText, cnHidden, cnReadOnly and cnDefaultInput.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a DataType set as cnBinary are:
cnFile*, cnHidden, cnReadOnly and cnDefaultInput.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a DataType set as cnGUID are:
cnText*, cnHidden, cnReadOnly and cnDefaultInput.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a DataType set as cnUnknown or cnUnsupported are:
None, an error is raised.
Available eInputTypes for inputs with a DataType set as cnChar or cnLongChar are:
cnText*, cnTextarea, cnHTMLEditor, cnPassword, cnHidden, cnReadOnly and cnDefaultInput.
* - eInputType utilised when cnDefaultInput is passed in.
NOTE: Inputs with a SaveType set as cnNonSearchableExType or cnVerbatumExType are rendered based on their DataType.

Thrown when the passed eInputType contains cnSingleValuePicklistExType and is defined as Picklist_IsAdHoc. Thrown when the passed eInputType contains cnMultiValuePicklistExType. Thrown when the passed sInputAlias is of an unknown or unsupported data type. Thrown when the passed sInputAlias has not be defined. Thrown when the global FormName is a null-string. ############################################################
Returns the length the passed page section crawls down a printed page.
This function is called once per page section when a Renderer.Report is being rendered in print mode. This means that you can calculate the page crawl on a per record basis if need be.
Due to the web's poor ability to format pages for printing, this method of counting the current number of units (inches, cm, mm, etc.) the current text would be on a printed page was devised. For example - if one record occupies approximately 1 inch of vertical page space, the top of the forth record would start at approximately 3 inches down the page. Though not perfect, this method allows the developer to better accommodate the printed page by controlling where page breaks occur.
NOTE: The units you choose to return from this function (inches, cm, mm, etc.) are irrelevant, so long as they agree with the units returned by the PageLength functions in the related RendererList, RendererForm and/or RendererReport.
Enumeration representing the referenced page section.
Integer representing the page crawl in units for the referenced ePageSection.

The provided sInitialValue is coerced into a boolean value (as a checkbox is boolean by nature). Because of this, the effective initial value of the input is returned so that end user data changes can be reconized despite this data transormation.
NOTE: The returned coerced sInitialValue is "true" if the value was determined to be true, or a null-string if it was determined to be false. A null-string is returned here in place of "false" because a non-checked checkbox submits as a null-string.
String representing the name of the input. String representing the additional HTML attributes to apply to the input. By reference String representing the initial value of the input. ###############################################################
Replaces all whitespace within the provided value with single spaces.
The term "normalize" in this instance conforms to XML's "collapse" style of text normalization. All occurrences of "tabs", "line feeds" and "carriage returns" are replaced with a "space". Subsequent to this, contiguous sequences of "spaces" are collapsed to a single "space", and initial and/or final "spaces" are deleted.
For additional information, please see "XML Schema Part 1, Section 3.1.4: White Space Normalization during Validation" available at "http://www.w3.org/TR/2001/REC-xmlschema-1-20010502/#section-White-Space-Normalization-during-Validation".

###############################################################
Determines if the provided value is a non-null string value.
This method checks for three distinct types of "null":
1) If the passed value is a null pointer, i.e. - equal to "null" (or "Nothing" in VB.Net).
2) If the passed value is a null-string, i.e. - equal to "".
3) If the passed value is a null character, i.e. - equal to ASCII character code 0.
If any one of these criteria are satisfied, the value is determined to be "null".
Object representing the value to test. Boolean value signaling if the passed oValue is a null value.
Returns true if the oValue is a null value, or false if it is not. ############################################################### January 25, 2010

###############################################################
Determines if the provided value is strictly numeric in nature.
This is essentually a stricter (as only some characters are considered numeric) while slopier (as order of those characters are not considerd) form of "IsNumber". This method ensures that the provided value only contains numeric characters (0-9, ",", "-" or "." only).
Due to its implementation, this method can handle numbers beyond the minimum/maximum values imposed by the language and/or system architecture.
The following examples of passed values and their related return values will help detail the use of this method:
"-9876.54" returns True
"-$9876.548" returns False
"-9876.548" returns False
"-9,876.54" returns True
"(9876.54)" returns False
"98-76.54" returns True
"Tell you what - 9 monkeys, 8 fish, 7 dogs and 6 cats. $54 in pet food." returns False
"-.-9.8.-.7.6.5.4." returns True
"- monkeys fish dogs cats." returns False
Numeric (Adj.); of or relating to or denoting numbers.
Object representing the value to test.
NOTE: This value is converted into its string equivalent before the test. Boolean value signaling if the passed oValue is numeric.
Returns true if the oValue can be successfully converted, or false if it cannot.
############################################################### February 15, 2006

###############################################################
Extracts any numeric data present within the provided value.
By most measures, this method is very "dumb". This method will extract all numeric data from the passed value indiscriminate of its position or the surrounding characters. The only intelligence this method utilizes is to determine if it will include a leading dash ("-") or a single decimal point (".") in the return value.
The following examples of passed values and their related return values will help detail the use of this method:
"-9876.54" returns -9876.54
"-$9876.548" returns -9876.54
"-9876.548" returns -9876.54
"-9,876.54" returns -9876.54
"(9876.54)" returns 9876.54
"98-76.54" returns 9876.54
"Tell you what - 9 monkeys, 8 fish, 7 dogs and 6 cats. $54 in pet food." returns -9876.54
"-.-9.8.-.7.6.5.4." returns -.987654
"- monkeys fish dogs cats." returns the default value
As you can see, a leading dash ("-") is perpended onto any following digits. The first decimal point (".") is also included positionally within any preceding/subsequent digits. Due to this behavior, this function is not intended to be used on random blocks of text. It is best used to force a "mostly" numeric value into a string, such as user supplied currency values (which is exactly how Renderer.Form uses it).
Object representing the value to query.
NOTE: This value is converted into its string equivalent before the test. String representing the value to return if the conversion fails. String representation of the numeric data within the passed oValue. If the conversion fails, the passed sDefaultValue is returned instead. ############################################################### August 27, 2007

Due to its implementation, this method can handle numeric values beyond the minimum/maximum values imposed by the language and/or system architecture.
"return (sNumber >= sRangeMin && sNumber <= sRangeMax)" would work in 99.9% of the checks we'll do with this function, but in the case of huge/tiny numbers (such as NUMERIC(x,y)'s in Oracle), this wouldn't cut it as the numbers would be too large/small to be represented in any available numeric datatypes.

Renders the error message associated with the Form input if an error is defined.
This function will render the error message associated with the Form input if an error has been defined. If no errors have been defined for the Form input, this function will return a null-string. This functionality allows you to avoid having to test each input for errors, and if an input has an error write out its . Simply call this function for all of your inputs if you have choosen not to use the popup style messages, and only those with errors will be rendered to the screen. The use of sMessageHead and sMessageTail allow you to further customize these error messages.

Safely retrieves the defined End User Messages Language Code.
There are two Language Codes maintained within the Cn.Web namespace:
1) The Developer's Language Code, which is stored within the global static Cn.Web.Settings.Internationalization instance.
2) The End User Messages Language Code, which is stored within Cn.Web.Settings.Current instances. This value defaults to the Developer's Language Code.
This method safely collects the defined End User Messages Language Code from the passed Cn.Web.Settings.Current instance. If the passed Cn.Web.Settings.Current instance is null, then the Language Code is sourced from the Developer's Language Code.

############################################################
Gets/sets a boolean value indicating if Picklists.Decodes utilize strict decodes.
This is utilized within Cn.Web.Inputs when rendering IsReadOnly inputs. This value defaults to the Cn.Web.Settings.Picklists currently set StrictDecodes, or false.
This logic is doubly defined here because of the way Picklist data is provided to Inputs.Builder, which is via a MultiArray containing the related Picklist and not via a native Picklist object (which includes it's definition for StrictDecodes). This approach allows the developer to provide ad-hoc picklists at run-time, which also need the ability to allow for StrictDecodes.
When "strict decodes" is enabled, only values present within the referenced picklist are returned from Decode calls.
In "strict decodes" mode: If the passed value to decode is not within the referenced picklist, a null-string is returned.
In non-"strict decodes" mode: If the passed value to decode is not within the referenced picklist, the passed value is returned.

############################################################
Gets/sets the current SQL order by clause.
The OrderBy clause is set by default based on the following order of prescience:
1) OrderBy equals the querystring's "OrderBy" field, as defined by the end-user (as long as it's safe).
2) Failing 1, OrderBy equals this instance's ResultsStack's "OrderedBy" field, as defined by the end-user (as long as it's safe).
3) Failing 1 and 2, OrderBy equals the DefaultOrderBy, as defined by the developer (as long as it's safe).
4) Failing 1, 2 and 3, OrderBy equals a null-string.
OrderBy clause values set via the OrderBy property overwrite this default value.
NOTE: The value of OrderBy is consumed when the Render function is called for a List, Form or Report. Because of this, this value should be modified previous to all Render calls if you are hoping to change the SQL order by clause.
Thrown when the provided value contains potentionally malicious SQL directives (as defined within Internationalization's "DisallowedUserStrings" and "DisallowedUserWords" picklists). ############################################################ May 15, 2007

1-based integer representing the current record index. Thrown when the passed value is less then 0. ############################################################ September 1, 2004

############################################################
Gets the realtive trail level.
The Level allows you to determine how the user is moving around site based on this instance's Breadcrumb Trail. Each TrailType behaves differently in relation to the Level, as detailed below.
For a cnHieratical Breadcrumb Trail, the following rules apply:
If the Level is 0, then the end-user is moving horizontally within the same file/page/mode/view as they were viewing on the last page load (i.e. - they are paging thru a list of results).
If the Level is 1, then the end-user is moving verticially downward (i.e. - they are "drilling down" into the results, such as viewing a "detail" page).
If the Level is a negetive number, then the end-user is moving verticially upward (i.e. - they are utilizing a bread crumb trail to navigate back up thru the site structure).
For a cnHistorical Breadcrumb Trail, the following rules apply:
If the Level is 1, then the file/page/view/mode is a new entry within the Breadcrumb Trail, so a new Breadcrumb Trail entry has been appended onto the trail.
If the Level is -1, then the file/page/view/mode already existed within the Breadcrumb Trail, so the current entry has been updated.
For a cnBreadCrumb Breadcrumb Trail, the following rules apply:
The Level is always 1, as we are always "moving down a level".
For a cnSelfManaged Breadcrumb Trail, the following rules apply:
In the default implementation, the Level is always 1, as the Breadcrumb Trail is self managed and we therefore have no way of telling what is going on, end-user movement wise.
Integer representing the realtive view level. ############################################################ December 21, 2009

############################################################
Gets a value indicating the view stack instance's type.
Enumeration indicating the view stack instance's type. ############################################################ December 21, 2009

member.name: F:Cn.Web.Breadcrumb.enumBreadcrumbTrailTypes.cnHieratical
member.summary:
Views (file/page/view/mode quartet) are appended and removed as the end-user moves up and down a hieratical site structure. A previous view (and all the subsequent views) are removed only if an exact match is found.
This trail functions as a LIFO (Last In First Out) queue, new views are added to the right of the trail.

member.name: F:Cn.Web.Breadcrumb.enumBreadcrumbTrailTypes.cnHistorical
member.summary:
Each view (file/page/view/mode quartet) is represented no more then once within the trail.
This trail functions as a non-determinate queue, new views are added to the right of the trail and existing file/page/view/mode quartets are overwritten in place.

member.name: F:Cn.Web.Breadcrumb.enumBreadcrumbTrailTypes.cnBreadCrumb
member.summary:
Each view (file/page/view/mode quartet) is indiscriminately added onto the end of the trail.
New views are added to the right of the trail.

member.name: F:Cn.Web.Breadcrumb.enumBreadcrumbTrailTypes.cnSelfManaged
member.summary:
View stack is managed externally by the developer.
The provided trail is not modified.

########################################################################################################################
Utility to collect values from either the provided data source or the user input based on the current context.
This class is provided as a utility to collect the current value of a column for a Renderer.Form. If it is the initial load of the Renderer.Form, the value is sourced from the provided DataTable object. If it is a subsequent page load (i.e. the user submitted an incomplete form), the value is sourced from the Request.Form object.
######################################################################################################################## February 20, 2006

This double-handeling is necessary as the g_oInputData is origionally setup in our Constructor as a non-.IsAttachedToDatasource input. So if the developer has defined an .IsAttachedToDatasource input, a re-definition of the g_oInputData is required before we can fulfill the request.
############################################################ June 24, 2010

############################################################
Gets the base control class related to this instance.
InputData object that manages this instance. ############################################################ February 8, 2010

############################################################
Gets/sets the parent input collection control related to this instance.
If an InputCollection has not been explicitly set, the following order of operations is undertaken to automaticially determine the Control representing an InputCollection:
1) InputCollectionID is used to find the developer specified control.
2) The Parent control is used.
3) The Page's Controls are searched recursively, and the first control found of type Controls.InputCollection is used.
4) The Page's Controls are searched recursively, and the first control found of type Controls.Form is used.
NOTE: If a Control is located, but is not of a type that represents an InputCollection, it is ignored and the next operation is undertaken to find a valid InputCollection-based control.
NOTE: It is far more efficient for the developer to place Cn:Input server tags directly under a Controls.InputCollection or Controls.Form, or to set an InputCollectionID then it is to rely on the inbuild searching mechnism. Besides, only the first found InputCollection-based control is returned which may or may not represent the correct InputCollection.
NOTE: This does not exactly serve the same purpose as InputData.Parent, as this referes to the control which itself holds a reference to the underlying IInputCollection object, as represented by InputData.Parent (so the control acts as a "man in the middle").
InputData object that manages this instance. ############################################################ June 24, 2010

############################################################

############################################################
Loads the provided pagination data into this instance.
A properly formed string representation of a Pagination class looks something like this:
OrderByClause:StartRecord|TableName1:IDColumn1:ID1:ID2:ID3|TableName2:IDColumn2:ID4:ID5
Where:
'|' represents the developer defined 'PrimaryDelimiter'.
':' represents the developer defined 'SecondaryDelimiter'.
'OrderByClause' represents the SQL compliant ordering statement.
'StartRecord' represents the 1-based positive interger indicating the starting record number for this 'results window'.
'TableName1'/'TableName2' represent 'table names' which signal to the developer the source of their associated 'IDs'. This value does not need to match the actual 'table name' within the underlying data source. This value is simply a signal to the developer indicating which underlying structure to use.
'IDColumn1'/'IDColumn2' represent 'ID column names' which signal to the developer where the associated 'IDs' are held. This value does not need to match the actual 'ID column name' within the underlying data source. This value is simply a signal to the developer indicating which underlying structure to use.
'ID1'...'ID5' represent the unique 'IDs' that individually identify a specific record within the associated 'table'.
NOTE: Each 'TableName:IDColumn' pair must be unique within an instance. This data is used to uniquely identify each collection of 'IDs'.
NOTE: Since this function is "foward facing" (meaning it deals with unscrubbed, user supplied data), errors are not raised. This function simply returns false if the passed sResultsStack is malformed.
String representing an instance of a Pagination class. Boolean value signaling if the data load was a success.
Returns true if the passed sResultsStack was successfully loaded, or false if it was not. ############################################################ January 12, 2006

############################################################
Loads the provided pagination data into this instance.
String representing the 'table name' within the underlying data source. String representing the 'ID column name' for the passed sTableName within the underlying data source. String representing the unique value that individually identifies a specific record.
If the passed sTableName/sIDColumn pair is already present within this instance, its 'IDs' collection is replaced by the passed sID (e.g. any current 'IDs' for the sTableName/sIDColumn pair are lost).
NOTE: Both sTableName and sIDColumn are compared as case insensitive.
NOTE: Each sTableName/sIDColumn pair must be unique within an instance. This data is used to uniquely identify each collection of 'IDs'.
############################################################ June 27, 2006

############################################################
Loads the provided pagination data into this instance.
String representing the 'table name' within the underlying data source. String representing the 'ID column name' for the passed sTableName within the underlying data source. String array representing the unique values that individually identify a specific records.
If the passed sTableName/sIDColumn pair is already present within this instance, its 'IDs' collection is replaced by the passed a_sIDs (e.g. any current 'IDs' for the sTableName/sIDColumn pair are lost).
NOTE: Both sTableName and sIDColumn are compared as case insensitive.
NOTE: Each sTableName/sIDColumn pair must be unique within an instance. This data is used to uniquely identify each collection of 'IDs'.
############################################################ June 27, 2006

member.name: T:Cn.Dates.enumWeekOfYearCalculations
member.summary: Defined week of year (week number) calculations.

member.name: F:Cn.Dates.enumWeekOfYearCalculations.cnDefault
member.summary: Default week of year (week number) calculation, which logicially equates to cnISO8601.

member.name: F:Cn.Dates.enumWeekOfYearCalculations.cnISO8601
member.summary: ISO 8601 week numbers (a.k.a. - the 4 day rule).
member.remarks:
ISO 8601 defines the Week as always starting with Monday being Day 1 and finishing with Sunday being Day 7. Therefore, the days of a single ISO Week can be in two different Calendar Years; and, because a Calendar Year has one or two more than 527 days, an ISO Year has either 52 or 53 Weeks.
Thus the ISO 8601 Week Numbers of a year are 01 to 52 or 53, which does not include zero. Part of Week 01 may be in the previous Calendar Year; part of Week 52 may be in the following Calendar Year; if a year has a Week 53, part of that week must be in the following Calendar Year. On average, six times out of seven, adjacent Dec 31st and Jan 1st are in the same Week. (quoted from: http://www.merlyn.demon.co.uk/weekinfo.htm#WkNo)

member.name: F:Cn.Dates.enumWeekOfYearCalculations.cnAbsolute
member.summary: Absolute week numbers (a.k.a - the Jan 1 rule).
member.remarks:
An absolute week number is the 7 day period that a date falls within, based solely on the first day of the year, regardless of the day of the week.
Week 1 is always Jan-1 to Jan-7, week 2 is always Jan-8 to Jan-14, and so on. If the year begins on a Thursday, then each "week" is from Thursday to the following Wednesday. The absolute week number will always be between 1 and 53. Week 53 will have either one or two days, depending on whether the year is a leap year. If the year is a not a leap year, week 53 will consist of one day: Dec-31. If the year is a leap year, week 53 will consist of two days: Dec-30 and Dec-31. (quoted from: http://www.cpearson.com/excel/weeknum.htm)

member.name: F:Cn.Dates.enumWeekOfYearCalculations.cnSimple_Sunday
member.summary: Simple week numbers, weeks beginning on Sunday.
member.remarks:
January 1st is always within week 1, and there are either 53 or 54 weeks in a year. This functions just like Excel's WeekNum function.
Week 1 is generally less than 7 days; and, about once per 28 years, there is a Week 54 consisting of Sunday Dec 31st, 2000 being one such year. (quoted from: http://www.merlyn.demon.co.uk/weekinfo.htm#WkNo)

############################################################
Formats the provided date based on the referenced format.
The provided date format is specified using the constants listed below. The provided examples, which are presented directly after each constant in parenthesis, are based on the following date: "2005-January-5 14:45:05 GMT".
* Year:
$YY (ex: 05)
$YYYY (ex: 2005)
* Month:
$M (ex: 1)
$MM (ex: 01)
$MMM (ex: Jan)
$MMMM (ex: January)
* Day:
$D (ex: 5)
$DD (ex: 5)
* Day Suffix (i.e.: 1st, 2nd, 3rd):
$S (ex: th)
* Day of Week (Sunday = 1 ... Saturday = 7):
$W (ex: 4)
$WWW (ex: Wed)
$WWWW (ex: Wednesday)
* Day of Year:
$J (ex: 5)
$JJJ (ex: 005)
* Week of Year (including its year, as required by ISO 8601 week numbers):
$w (ex: 1)
$ww (ex: 01)
$yy (ex: 05)
$yyyy (ex: 2005)
NOTE: These values are based on the week numbering scheme referenced by eWeekOfYearCalculation. There are a host of other week numbering schemes (see: http://www.merlyn.demon.co.uk/weekinfo.htm#WkNo, http://www.merlyn.demon.co.uk/weekcalc.htm#NIP and http://www.merlyn.demon.co.uk/js-dates.htm), many of which seem to be anything but "standard". If you require a different week numbering scheme, please contact Nick Campbeln via email: "renderer_weeknumbering@nick.campbeln.com".
* UNIX Epoch Timestamp:
$E (ex: 1104936305)
* 24 Hour:
$H (ex: 14)
$HH (ex: 14)
* 12 Hour:
$h (ex: 2)
$hh (ex: 2)
* Mederian (i.e.: am/pm):
$tt (ex: pm)
* Minute:
$m (ex: 45)
$mm (ex: 45)
* Second:
$s (ex: 5)
$ss (ex: 05)
* Escaped dollar sign:
$$ (ex: $)

############################################################
Determines the ISO 8601 week number (also known as the 4 day rule) for the given date.
Based on code written by Simen Sandelien and provided (without license) at "http://konsulent.sandelien.no/VB_help/Week/".
The .NET GetWeekOfYear() method will NOT produce correct ISO 8601 week numbers regardless of culture or CalendarWeekRule settings. Here is an explanation of the problem, as well as a custom method that does the right calculation.
I [Simen Sandelien] recently encountered a situation where I needed my C#.NET application to display the correct week number associated with a date. Knowing that the different countries of the world have different rules associated with their calendars I assumed that this would be the perfect situation to bring in the new culture features of .NET. Here in Norway, and apparently in many other parts of Europe we use the so called FirstFourDayWeek rule to determine which week (at the beginning of the year) is supposed to be week number 1. In the USA they use the so called FirstDay rule to determine the same thing.
DateTime representing the date in question. Array of 1-based integers where the first index represents the ISO week number (1-53) for the passed date and the second index represents the ISO week number's associated year. ############################################################ March 2, 2007
